page.title: 17Male unemployment in Bilston
page.content: Bilston, a traditional area for heavy industry, has suffered from the re- location of iron and steel works to coastal sites. British Steel provided many of the local population with work, but since its closure in 1979 the area has experienced high unemployment. It is noticeable that more men are helping their wives with shopping, and the traditional role of "breadwinner" is changing. They are more involved with housework,child rearing,and decorating. More men are seen pushing prams and pushchairs while mother is at work. Others spend more time watching TV, sleeping, drinking more,especially at lunchtime when other unemployed friends gravitate to the local pub. Many school pupils seem resigned to not obtaining jobs and truancy has increased. Exams are seen as less important;and a sense of apathy prevails in the classroom.
